title: Thursday, 11th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE

Hello, hi, welcome.

BE

But enough with the formalities, let's take a look at the movers.

BE

11:02 am
BE

Yup.

BE

All a bit ugly out there.

BE

FTSE seeing if it can break below 5,500.

11:03 am
BE

Euro Stoxx down 3.6%

BE

Cac 40 off 3.8%.

BE

Dax down 2.9%.

11:03 am
BE

In terms of individual movers, we have StanChart

BE

(whose rescue rights issue a few months ago was at 465p)

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 387.15, down 20.25 (-4.97%), High: 409.45, Low: 373.40, Volume: 4.08m
11:04 am
BE

And Glencore

BE

(Whose rescue rights issue a few months ago was at 125p)

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 89.52, down 3.98 (-4.26%), High: 92.11, Low: 87.10, Volume: 23.40m
11:05 am
BE

Given these moves, what chance anyone else can get a rescue rights issue away?

BE

Let's not even mention Lonmin here.

BE

But to banks. What brought this on?

11:06 am
BE

SocGen numbers are pretty bad, I guess.

BE

Clean PBT misses by 10% on higher costs and provisions.

BE

But it's SocGen. We can't read much through from that.

11:07 am
BE

It seems instead that we've moved into spiral territory.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 150.34, down 8.66 (-5.45%), High: 157.50, Low: 148.65, Volume: 37.03m
HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 424.40, down 17 (-3.85%), High: 435.45, Low: 420.80, Volume: 15.26m
11:07 am
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 56.69, down 1.71 (-2.92%), High: 57.78, Low: 55.84, Volume: 57.59m
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 224.80, down 8.2 (-3.52%), High: 230.40, Low: 220.90, Volume: 7.17m
BE

Lots of sellside around saying buy the drop.

11:08 am
BE

Morningstar, for instance.

BE

We think the sell-off is overdone for several reasons. First, for most European banks, the exposure to the energy sector--both direct and indirect--is more than manageable. Investment-grade energy bonds are pricing in losses of roughly 15%, which would result in losses of only 4.5% of common equity value, or six months of earnings for a bank otherwise achieving a 10% return on tangible common equity, and 3.6% or just above one quarter of earnings excluding the two most exposed European banks. Second, while lower-for-longer interest rates will be a near-term headwind for European banks, we've long anticipated a slow improvement in the economic environment, and we think recent optimism with regards to a strong European recovery was too much. We further note that some of the hardest hit banks such as UniCredit (where the CEO is under pressure to step down) have been some of the slowest to restructure post-crisis, indicating in our view, a level of frustration by investors at the pace of restructuring within the Italian banking system. This is a signal to other European banks they will be penalized with low valuations until management teams undertake more aggressive changes or risk being ousted themselves as we've seen recently with the changes at Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse, Barclays, and Standard Chartered. Finally, counterparty risk and notional derivative exposures are at the top of investors' minds. Here too, we believe fears are overblown. Net exposures to individual asset classes, events, or counterparties are relatively manageable-especially in the case of interest rates which make up a bulk of reported notional exposures.

BE

Jason Napier at UBS also saying buy the drop.

11:09 am
BE

Banks are trading at distressed PE and P/TNAV multiples. Emerging Market/China/
APAC slowdown and Oil going to US$30 are potentially triggering a downturn in the
credit cycle and concerns over credit/exposure quality in general. High-yield spreads as a
result of this have widened sharply: They almost doubled from summer 2015 to above
800bp now. US HY funds have seen redemptions accelerating recently and they
totalled US$20bn Q2-Q4 2015. Mark-to-market in Q4 losses (more to come in Q1?) are
weighing on banks' profitability which is already low due to low client activity levels,
low interest rates and high cost levels and relatively low short-term cost flex.

BE

A vicious circle – Are banks in better shape today? Yes

BE

Widening spreads and low profitability of some banks have triggered concerns around
the banks' ability to service and issue AT1 bonds. The most vulnerable banks' share
prices were those with 1) EM/energy exposure 2) AT1 issuances ahead 3) low current
profitability 4) large capital market/IB positions such as Deutsche Bank or Credit Suisse.
In general, the banks' ability to absorb shocks has improved a lot we think, e.g., the
readiness of central banks to provide liquidity to the banks is an additional support.

11:09 am
BE

UBS also gives us this handy table of AT1s.

BE

Now, one could argue that investors seem to have lost trust in the safety nets working, but they do at least exist. That's undeniable.

BE

11:11 am
BE

So ...........

BE

What can stop the downward spiral and what banks to buy?
A (short-term) stabilisation in credit markets and the oil price or even a recovery could
stabilise the situation. Additional disclosure and statements by the banks would also
help to increase confidence (or remove concerns) we think. Short-term rallies are likely.
We would focus on primarily domestic driven retail and commercial banks, limited
capital market gearing, strong capital and funding and liquidity positions and yield
potential: Lloyds, ING, Partners Group, Cembra, Barclays for those who want to have
some IB exposure. CS and DBK are Neutral given exogenous vulnerabilities and low
visibility.

BE

(@markopolo: I don't think anyone's arguing that point. I think the core of the argument is whether a bank trading at 0.4 times book is being priced for stagnation or default.)

11:12 am
BE

JP Morgan Caz, also, saying buy the drop.

BE

Carney to the rescue, basically.

BE

With rising credit spreads implying a higher cost of equity, we believe that the
market is yet to price in a more supportive UK regulatory stance on bank
capital indicated in Dec’15. UK Banks have proactively taken action on
capital driven by pressure from the FPC in 2013-15, as reflected in leverage
ratios above 4% and CT1 above 2018 known requirements. This keeps us
positive on a medium-term view, but we are now assuming a weaker earnings
backdrop. We are cutting our 2018 EPS estimates by up to c23%, although
this still leaves the sub-sector trading at an inexpensive 6.2x PE, ex HSBC at
9.2x 2018E. Our UK top pick remains Lloyds (Analyst Focus List stock),
where we now expect 2015 DPS of 2p (3.4% yield) with 0.75p DPS deferred
to 2016-18 due to front-loading of PPI costs. Our pecking order is Lloyds,
Barclays, StanChart, RBS and HSBC.

11:13 am
BE

 Don’t ignore the message from the BOE: We note Governor Carney’s
comments that UK banks are well capitalized and the next move in UK rates
is likely upwards, which underpins a supportive backdrop for dividends and
NIM. In a backdrop of rising market concern over credit spreads, we
highlight that UK bank leverage ratios are already above requirements,
which allows more flexibility around issuance of AT1 in a sector context.
 Barclays: At 0.6x P/TNAV 2016E, the market appears to be discounting
share count risk; we forecast a 12% CT1 by 2017E and flag that a
deteriorating IB revenue environment could provide the catalyst for change.
We believe new CEO Jes Staley can move Barclays away from the value
trap by re-allocating capital away from the IB, which is a sub-7% RoTE
business, into the rest of Barclays' Core businesses, which have an ROTE of
14%. Cutting IB capital allocation by 30% would, on our calculations, close
the group's capital deficit to fund a rising dividend by releasing c70bps CT1
and lower the implied cost of equity of 16.3%.

BE

 StanChart & HSBC: Both banks face earnings pressure from the EM credit
cycle, but we believe StanChart has addressed its capital concerns with CT1
at 12.8-13.6% over 2015-18 and the outlook for EM/Commodities is now
reflected in valuation at 0.5x P/TNAV ’15E and 5x ‘18E PE. Despite our
EPS cuts, for StanChart we are 2% above 2017E company consensus EPS.
For HSBC, we are c20% below consensus 2017E EPS and remain UW.
 Changes to estimates: We cut our adj. EPS est. for Barclays by 6-7%,
HSBC by 8-23% and STAN by 18-46% due to lower expected revenues in
IB & EM and higher EM provisions. As a result, we cut our Dec-16 PTs for
Barclays to 260p (-10%), HSBC to 430p (-14%) & STAN to 725p (-17%).

BE

So .................... heading into the detail of that Caz one ....

11:14 am
BE

The bit that caught my eye was on BarCap.

BE

Caz going for another bonfire of the IB.

BE

Because it's currently being valued by the market at -- get this! --- minus £5bn.

11:15 am
BE

Honestly. Look.

BE

BE

(Right click and open in new window to make readable. We can't do "click to enlarge" on the fly, sadly.)

11:17 am
BE

That means, by my numbers, that Barclays' 25,000 IB employees are worth minus £2m each.

BE

How do you get up in the morning knowing that you're worth minus £2m to the company?

BE

And, just by sacking a third of them, Barclays CET1 goes up by 70 bips.

11:18 am
BE

In a scenario where Barclays shrinks its IB by 30% by FY17E with proportional
impact on revenues and costs and restructuring costs equivalent to 1.5x the cost
saves, 2017E CT1 improves by c70bps and IB as % of group RWAs reduces from
31% to 24% pre harmonisation. We believe this would allow the new CEO to fund a
rising dividend and would lead to the market attaching a lower cost of equity which
we estimate is implied at 16.3% at the current share price.

BE

Anyway.

BE

Oh, did I add an extra zero or two? I'm not good with a calculator.

11:19 am
BE

Minus £200k. Whatever.

undefined
BE

Actually, want some more "buy the drop" stuff?

11:20 am
BE

UBS again. Quant team this time.

BE

At these levels it normally pays to buy value – however awful it might feel

BE

Because, oil.

11:21 am
BE

And the correlations therein. Because past performance is a guide to future returns, as I'm fairly sure the small print always says.

BE

(@Soundbuy: nope, I only calculate the readership figures.)

BE

The distaste for value is back to the 'growth love-in' high of 2000. The valuation stretch
between winners & losers (within a sector) has only been this high 4 times since 2000:
1) end of Tech bubble; 2) Mar 03 recession; 3) Mar 09 Financial crisis; and 4) Jul 12
'euro panic'. To get into the Red Circle investors have to feel pretty ill about the future.
If we look 12 months beyond these peak gaps, the performance of Value was up on
average 20% (higher post 2000!) and for Quality down 21%. In our view, unless we
have another big crisis, it would be dangerous to be positioned against this.

11:21 am
BE

By "red circle" they mean this.

BE

BE

Oil is the culprit: Correlation to Value, European Equities & Banks is extreme

11:22 am
BE

We link Oil & Value in this note because Oil seems to be the key driver of the value gap.
The correlation between Oil and 'sector neutral' Value has moved with Oil and is near a
2 year high. The link to European Equities (fig 1) and Banks (fig 7) is extreme.

BE

And, true, it does look extreme.

BE

11:22 am
BE

BE

3 perceived impacts of collapsing Oil. We think worries are overdone

BE

1. Financial contagion? European Energy dividend pay-out ratio triples from 2007 but
we've been here before, in 1998. Plus, if we look at European banks exposure to
Energy it is less than 3% of loans. 2. Hit to earnings? Energy & Mining's share
of profits has fallen by 60% and is less potent. 3. Global Growth? We think the US
shock is behind us and take comfort that the EM growth premium to DM has
unwound back to 2000 levels Plus 75% of EM countries are oil importers.

11:23 am
BE

So if you assume we're past the worst, buy "value" and sell "quality"

BE

A strategy that's done a 20% return on average since Y2K.

BE

11:24 am
BE

Oil-Sensitive stocks that fall into Cheap & Expensive camps in our value screen
UBS analysts flag oil sensitive stocks. We select 1) stocks hurt by falling oil that
underperformed and are cheap via our intra-sector value screen, such as: Weir, E.ON,
Engie and Lanxess; and 2) stocks that have benefited from falling oil that
outperformed and are expensive such as: Frutarom, Kingspan, Symrise, Ems-Chemi and
Givaudan.

BE

(@Penny: that's a very good point. I suspect you're 100% correct.)

undefined
11:27 am
BE

Okay, good to see the ROTR busy today. Requests welcome, as it's never easy in an everything-down day.

BE

In terms of miners, Glencore ........

BE

Overnight streaming deal confirmed at the same disappointing price as was leaked to the Sunday Times

11:28 am
BE

Did I say leaked? Sorry, I meant dropped.

BE

Sorry, sorry. Not dropped. "Reported by". That's the phrase.

BE

And production is ... well, who gives a damn?

11:01 am
BE

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily whatever.

BE

Here's Goldman on the streaming deal.

BE

Glencore signed a precious metals streaming deal at its Antapaccay mine
with Franco-Nevada. Franco-Nevada will make an upfront payment of
US$500mn to Glencore upon completion of the transaction which is
expected by end February. Thereafter, Franco-Nevada will make ongoing
payments of 20% of spot gold and silver price per ounce delivered which
will increase to 30% of spot prices after 750koz of gold and 12,800koz of
silver have been delivered. In return, Glencore will deliver 300oz of gold
per 1kt of copper in concentrate up until 630koz of gold have been
delivered and 30% of gold production thereafter; and 4.7koz of silver per
1kt of copper in concentrate up until 10,000koz of silver have been
delivered and 30% of silver production thereafter.

11:30 am
BE

Yesterday’s (February 10) streaming deal is the second streaming deal
announced by Glencore as part of its debt reduction measures. By the
investor day in December 2015, Glencore had locked-in $8.7bn of the up to
$13.1bn debt reduction target. With yesterday’s deal, the overall debt
reduction measures locked-in will increase to $9.2bn (or 70% of its target).
While the streaming deal reduces the net debt of Glencore, the impact on
earnings is likely to be c.$69mn per annum on 2015 production numbers
and spot gold/silver prices.
While Glencore is delivering on its debt reduction plans, we believe the
issue for the company continues to remain falling commodity prices such
as copper where spot prices are c.13% lower than when the company
originally announced its debt reduction plans

BE

And RBC on production, in case anyone cares.

BE

Strong production from Metals & Mining: Copper production for 4Q15 came in at 375kt, 13% above RBC at 332kt, with zinc production at 318kt, 4% ahead of our forecast of 305kt. The copper beat was predominately driven by strong performance at Antamina (38.6kt vs. RBC at 28.6kt) and higher than expected production at Antapaccay (49.9kt vs. RBC 40kt). The higher than expected zinc production was driven by Kazzinc with production of 51.4kt vs. RBC at 42.2kt.
Lead production was significantly higher than our forecast at 69.2kt vs RBC at 38.6kt while Nickel was slightly ahead at 27.5kt vs RBC 25.5kt.

11:31 am
BE

Energy slightly weaker while production from Agriculture remains strong: Total coal production came in at 28.8mt for 4Q15, 14% below our forecast of 33.5mt. While Australian thermal coal production was in line with expectations, the other divisions delivered weaker production. Oil on a gross basis was 6% higher than our forecast on the back of stronger volumes from Equatorial Guinea, while production from the Ags division was also higher driven by higher
volumes from the crushing division.

BE

GLEN releases strong FY16 guidance: Guidance for the Metals & Mining division is primarily ahead of our forecast with copper guidance of ~1,390kt vs RBC 1,327kt, Zinc guidance of ~1,095kt vs RBC 1,044kt, Lead guidance of ~285kt vs RBC 232kt and Nickel in line at ~116kt. Guidance for oil production was slightly below our forecast at ~8,500kbbl vs RBC 9,400kbbl and Coal was in line at 130mt.

undefined
11:32 am
BE

On Rio, I guess the divi cut is the interesting bit.

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 1,694, down 71.5 (-4.05%), High: 1,733, Low: 1,605, Volume: 4.45m
BE

Or a policy reset, or a rebasing, or however one wishes to present it.

11:34 am
BE

Otherwise, the numbers show Rio to be the better operator in a bad neighborhood.

BE

Morgan Stanley incoming .......

BE

These results show RT is embracing reality and aiming to find a better balance
between; returning cash, maintaining a strong balance sheet and re-investing
somewhat for future growth. Growth capex remains US$2-3bn per year which
is still reasonably significant on the book value of equity of US$44bn. RT's
valuation at 9.1x EV/EBITDA and 4.5% FCF yield on spot is reasonable if this is
the bottom of the cycle. The key risk obviously remains a further decline in
commodity prices with each US$5 per ton in iron ore reducing FCF by
US$0.9bn.

11:35 am
BE

New dividend policy shows the group embraces reality: The 2015 total
dividend is set at US$2.15 inline with our forecasts. For 2016 the minimum
dividend is set at US$1.10 per share or US$2.0bn. From 2017 onwards the
board will set the dividend on a year by year basis. It aims on average over the
cycle to have a 40-60% pay-out ratio of underlying earnings but can be above
or below this in an individual year. On our current estimates using spot
commodity prices a 40-60% pay-out ratio would lead to US$1.0-1.8bn of
dividend for 2017-2019 on average. However those estimates do not yet
include the US$1bn pre tax savings in 2016 and potentially US$1.0bn in 2017.
At US$1.10 RT's dividend yield amounts to 4.4% and it is covered by FCF on
spot in 2016.

BE

Capex cut to focus only on core projects: Guidance drops to US$4bn in 16
(was less than 6), US$5bn in 17 (was less than 7) and US$5.5bn in 18 (no previous guidance). US$0.5bn of the cuts comes from the reduction in maintenance capex that
drops from US$2.5bn to US$2.0bn. The rest is from a reduction in growth
capex. Half of that is from weaker FX and cheaper purchasing. The rest is from
delays in all projects except: Amrun, Oyu Tolgoi phase 2 and Silvergrass.

BE

Net debt slightly better at US$13.8bn (MSe US$14.0bn). However, gearing increased to 24% as the book value of equity dropped by US$10.5bn affected by Fx translation
(US$2.4bn), the buyback (US$2bn) and the dividend (US$4.1bn). The leverage
ratio remains in the bottom half of the guidance range of 20-30%. FCF
amounted to US$4.8bn or US$0.2bn ahead of our estimates with a strong
working capital inflow in 2H15

11:37 am
undefined
BE

Service note -- the powers that be have rejigged the comment system slightly overnight.

BE

You may find more often that your comment is stuck in the purgatory we call "pending"

11:38 am
BE

There's probably a workaround, but we've not figured one out yet.

BE

For now, though, if you say something that's not wildly offensive and it doesn't appear, apologies.

BE

It's just trapped, not lost, and will be added to the transcript eventually.

11:40 am
BE

Service note ends.

undefined
BE

Okay, so is there anything less gloomy to look at?

11:41 am
BE

Perhaps someone can explain this Johnston Press deal to me.

Johnston Press PLC (JPR:LSE): Last: 39.00, down 0.75 (-1.89%), High: 41.00, Low: 39.00, Volume: 105.85k
BE

As shaken out by the Telegraph overnight. In late-stage talks to buy I.

11:42 am
BE

Not the Independent, just I.

BE

The tabloid version of the Independent that's made entirely of Independent copy.

BE

Aside from speculating why Lebedev might need the money, I'm struggling to see the logic here.

11:44 am
BE

Ditto Peel Hunt, which says .....

BE

Life at Johnston Press is never dull. Having just announced ‘a
reduction of pension deficit’, JPR is now in advanced talks to
acquire the i for c£24m. This looks to be a transaction multiple of
c4.5x EBIT, and hence not supportive of JPR’s own current EV
multiple. We cannot imagine bond holders or pension trustees
will be happy. JPR had cash at hand of c£41m at H1, but gross
debt of c£225m, and operating trends have been deteriorating
sharply since then. We are in favour of print industry
consolidation (see our Media Book published today). However,
we are confused by JPR’s business strategy as a regional
publisher, which has focussed on paring back print, in favour of
digital. The i is an innovative product, but it is wholly print and
national. Nationals is a very competitive space, with TNI
amongst others rumoured to be in launch mode. Shareholder
approval of this deal will be needed.

BE

How can you even calculate 4.5x EBIT? Where are you placing the costs?

11:45 am
BE

PR about to buy the i? In yet another RNS, JPR has stated it is in ‘late stage
discussions’ to buy the i. We were aware that the i (and the Independent assets)
were informally on the block, but we admit to being a little bit ‘blindsided’ by
this outcome.
Cost/multiple: JPR suggest £24m cash consideration. This is about 4.5x ‘carve
out operating profit’. So the multiple is low-ish, and not supportive of JPR’s own
valuation. We cannot see any £m synergies identified. It is not clear what
headcount comes across with this business, at a time when JPR is culling its
own staff.
Impact on estimates: Notionally, this would add c10% to group EBITA. Note,
however, JPR is also looking to sell some regional assets at present, so group
EBITA for FY 16 is in flux.
Strategy: JPR justifies the ‘i deal’ on the back of : 1 Print reach enlarged;
2 increased share of national advertising; 3/ ‘Growing revenues’; 4/ Accelerated
digital transformation’. Superficially, this looks promising. However, nationals is
a very different space to regionals, and the likes of Trinity are pursuing an organic
approach to ‘low-price’ nationals.
Investment comment: The bond price remains in the low 70s, on a downward
trend. This i deal is notionally EPS accretive of course, perhaps as much as 8%
ceteris paribus. However, our initial thoughts are that it should be rejected by
stakeholders, on the basis of opportunity cost.

BE

And if J Press buys the I, can the Independent just make another one?

BE

Is it buying the egg rather than the chicken?

11:46 am
BE

Can Lebedev keep on laying little Independents and selling them for £24m each?

BE

Will the next one be called N? Then D? E, P, etc.

BE

Unless the idea is to buy I, shut down the Independent and inherit its name.

11:48 am
BE

As some kind of face-saving move by Levedev.

BE

It's just surreal.

undefined
11:49 am
BE

@uclallum: I've heard nothing corporate around Genel for some time.

Genel Energy PLC (GENL:LSE): Last: 95.75, down 2.75 (-2.79%), High: 98.25, Low: 91.75, Volume: 3.33m
BE

In fact, any time I mention the idea to an industry person, it sparks a half-hour discussion about the impossibility of doing business in Kurdistan.

11:51 am
BE

There's an interesting disjoin between the tone of the message from KRG operators and those familiar with conditions on the ground.

BE

Anyway, we had a Tawke update today, which Stifel can talk us through.

BE

This morning Genel's operating partner at the Tawke field in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, DNO (DNO.NO, NOK6.035, not covered), announced in its 4Q15 results that it expects production at the asset to rise to 135 kbbls/d, from the current c.120 kbbls/d level. The move reinforces Genel CFO Ben Monaghan's comments (Reuters, 9 February) that development drilling in the region would resume in the coming weeks, and suggests to us that the seeming normalisation of payments from the government to the oil companies is having the desired effect, i.e. to promote investment. Our current financials, reproduced on page 2 of this report, assume continued declines at Tawke for a 115 kbbls/d gross annual average, so this aspiration, if realised, would likely result in a small improvement in our view of cash flow generation potential this y

11:52 am
BE

DNO's comments this morning: "Expect Tawke production to climb from
120,000 barrels of oil per day to 135,000 bbls/d by mid-year, with further
increases to follow as additional investments [are] made".
This follows the Kurdistan Regional Government beginning to pay companies
in line with their entitlement, rather than on a more arbitrary (although still
monthly) basis as has been the case up until this month. The quid pro quo for
this normalisation, it seems, is that renewed investment is required of the
international oil companies.
Detail
The company is planning a net $100m capital programme, of which the bulk
will be spent in Kurdistan (no precise breakdown provided). This will involve
new production wells, water handling facilities as well as an appraisal on the
Peshkabir discovery (within the licence), which can be quickly tied in. We find
it interesting to note that appraisal opportunities are therefore broadly
NPV-equivalent with development drilling.

undefined
BE

(@Soundbuy: nope, sorry. It's not a good day to be a bandit.)

11:54 am
BE

Anything needing covered in our last few minutes?

BE

I'll try and find some gold stat before we end, in response to popular demand.

BE

In the meantime, I doubt there's huge interest in DCC.

11:55 am
BE

The Irish petrol station operator that's somehow found itself in the FTSE 100.

DCC PLC (DCC:LSE): Last: 5,095, up 80 (+1.60%), High: 5,280, Low: 5,070, Volume: 334.08k
BE

Q3's fine, in short.

11:56 am
BE

There had been worries about weather

BE

A warm winter equals lower demand for fuel. But this time it hasn't, so statement in line and shares rally.

BE

Davy says ........

11:57 am
BE

DCC’s Q3 IMS provides further evidence of the attractiveness of
its business model. The group continues to deliver significant
profit growth, largely independent of the economic backdrop.
We think there are very few industrial companies globally that
can deliver this type of performance currently. As such, we
believe that the stock remains significantly undervalued at
17.7x 2017 P/E. The balance sheet is in excellent shape and
acquisition opportunities remain large. Energy in particular has
exciting prospects ahead. Outperform.

undefined
BE

(@chopper: still doing this big US acquisition, no? Haven't heard anything beyond that.)

11:59 am
BE

(Apart from the usual rumblings about infrastructure funds being interested, but haven't heard those for at least a month.)

BE

(@leckford: I'm not on Albert's distribution list. My sunny personality couldn't cope with it.)

BE

Okay! Gold. Best thing I've found is from Paradigm Capital .....

12:01 pm
BE

Who I think are Canadian.

BE

This all feels somewhat obvious to me, but might help reinforce your own prejudices.

BE

Gold Price – Safe-Haven Reputation Rebuilding & USD Rolling Over | These
two factors are working in gold’s favour, the latter because expectations are
growing that the Fed will delay rate increases. The former is a constructive sign
that a bottom has been put in place for the cycle; this, along with encouraging
technical/chart action, is helping draw a wider buying audience than we have seen
for several months.

12:02 pm
BE

Deflation – Increasingly a Consideration | The number of signals that the global
economies are descending into a deflationary environment continues to grow. We
have analyzed gold’s historical performance in deflationary circumstances. Like a
currency, gold retained its buying power better than other asset classes, which
suffered value deflation.

BE

Learning From Past Cycles | In 2015, the seasonal rally peaked in late February,
and in 2014 it ended in mid-March. It is too early to say that this rally is part of a
“new paradigm”. Past cycle recoveries have generally started haltingly. Recall that
gold anticipates the dollar by 3–5 months and gold stocks anticipate the metal by
a similar amount, so we must think at least a half year ahead. Given how quickly
conditions have changed since December (ask the Fed), it’s hard to imagine what
the global economy and markets will look like by mid-2016.

BE

Gold Miners – A Better Business Model | While they still have much to do to
convince generalist investors that their business model is worthy of investment,
gold miners should show a meaningful improvement in margins this year. The
current $1,189/oz metal price compares to the $1,109/oz it averaged in Q4/15 and

Senior share prices are 38% higher than at the start of the year, while the
Intermediate, Junior and Royalty tiers are up 14%, 24% and 7%, respectively.
Impressive as these might seem, they still leave the median Intermediate-tier producer
at only 27% of its high price since 2010. The Intermediates are the most functional tier
for investment purposes, in our opinion, particularly for generalists. Our favourites
remain: Agnico-Eagle, Alamos, Franco-Nevada and Detour. We would also consider
Kinross (Under Review).
